questions.text: Which band is known as the 'Fab Four'?
questions.explanation: The Beatles (John, Paul, George, and Ringo) are famously known as the Fab Four.

questions.text: Which festival took place in 1969 and became a symbol of the counterculture generation?
questions.explanation: Woodstock was a pivotal moment in music history, taking place in upstate New York in August 1969.

questions.text: Who sang the hit song 'Respect' in 1967?
questions.explanation: Aretha Franklin's version of 'Respect' became an anthem for civil rights and women's rights.

questions.text: Which Motown group launched the career of Diana Ross?
questions.explanation: Diana Ross was the lead singer of The Supremes, Motown's most commercially successful act.

questions.text: Bob Dylan controversially 'went electric' at which event in 1965?
questions.explanation: Dylan was booed by folk purists when he played an electric guitar set at the Newport Folk Festival.

questions.text: Who released the concept album 'Pet Sounds' in 1966?
questions.explanation: Brian Wilson and The Beach Boys released 'Pet Sounds', often cited as one of the greatest albums of all time.

questions.text: Which song begins with the lyrics 'Hello darkness, my old friend'?
questions.explanation: 'The Sound of Silence' by Simon & Garfunkel became a major hit in 1965.

questions.text: Which artist is known for the song 'Purple Haze'?
questions.explanation: Jimi Hendrix released 'Purple Haze' in 1967, showcasing his revolutionary guitar style.

questions.text: The 'British Invasion' refers to the popularity of British bands in the US during which decade?
questions.explanation: The movement began in the mid-1960s, led by The Beatles.

questions.text: Who sang 'I Got You Babe' with Sonny Bono?
questions.explanation: Sonny & Cher's signature song 'I Got You Babe' was a number one hit in 1965.
The Beach Boys' 'Good Vibrations' is famous for its complex production and use of the theremin-like electro-theremin.

questions.text: Otis Redding is best known for which song, released posthumously?

options.B: (Sittin' On) The Dock of the Bay

questions.explanation: Redding recorded it just days before his death in a plane crash in 1967.

questions.text: Which TV show created a made-for-TV band that rivaled the Beatles in sales for a brief period?
questions.explanation: The Monkees were created for the TV show but eventually fought for creative control over their music.

questions.text: Jim Morrison was the lead singer of which band?
questions.explanation: Jim Morrison, the 'Lizard King', fronted The Doors until his death in 1971.

questions.text: Who sang 'These Boots Are Made for Walkin''?
questions.explanation: Nancy Sinatra had a massive hit with this Lee Hazlewood song in 1966.
